definitions.definition: used when showing that something is or was possible

examples.text: He might get there in time, but I can't be sure.
It might not be too late to save the building.
I know Vicky doesn't like the job, but I mightn't find it too bad.
The pills might have helped him, if only he'd taken them regularly.
He might say that now *(= it is true that he does)*, but he can soon change his mind.
He might, if he chose, retire and live in luxury for the rest of his days.

definitions.definition: used as the past tense of may when reporting what somebody has said

examples.text: He said he might come tomorrow.
Zheng said she might not stay in the city for long.

definitions.definition: used to make a polite suggestion

examples.text: You might try calling the help desk.
I thought we might go to the zoo on Saturday.
Might I use your phone?
If I might just say something…
How might the plans be improved upon?
And who might she be?

definitions.definition: used to show that you are annoyed about something that somebody could do or could have done

examples.text: I think you might at least offer to help!
Honestly, you might have told me!

definitions.definition: used to say that you are not surprised by something

examples.text: I might have guessed it was you!
Her film was full of magical effects, as you might expect.

definitions.definition: used to emphasize that an important point has been made

examples.text: ‘And where is the money coming from?’ ‘You **might well** ask!’

definitions.definition: used to say that something seems the best thing to do in the situation that you are in, although you may not really want to do it

examples.text: If no one else wants it, we might as well give it to him.

definitions.definition: used to say that there is no real difference between two things that you might do

examples.text: If you are going to have sugar, you may as well have a bar of chocolate.
